text: A limerick is a funny, silly, rude, or sexual poem that has five (or four) lines. Lines 1, 2, and 5 rhyme with each other and have eight (or more) syllables. Lines 3 and 4 have a different rhyme word and have five (or more) syllables each. The poem often begins with "There was a ...", but it doesn't have to. This one is by Rudyard Kipling: A limerick by Edward Lear, who is famous for writing this kind of poem, has four lines because he combines lines 3 and 4 into one ten-syllable line: == Related pages == *Poetry *Blank verse *Free verse *Verse-chorus form *Ballad *Rhyme *Stanza *Ode *Sonnet ==References== Category:Poetry forms
title: Limerick (poetry)
